ooking: Gourmet Sausage Making Come along and learn how to fill sausage casings with a tasty mincemeat and get tips and tricks on how to make your own customized sausage mixes at home with the use of various herbs and spices.
Everyone will get some sausages to take home and enjoy.
All ingredients included in course fee but please bring your apron, a dish cloth and a couple of tea towels to the session.
By the end of the course, you’ll be able to: - Recognise how to handle a knife safely - Understand food safety and hygiene around sausage-making and avoiding cross contamination - Recognise the difference between two kinds of sausage casings and why you use each of them - Have some ideas on how to make and cook a good quality sausage properly - Be able to safely store sausages products Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel.
If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

events.id: Drizzle Sizzle - Karahui & Blue Earth Estate-Karahui Wine Bar & Eatery, 1 Memorial Square, Martinborough-Event Finder
events.name: Drizzle Sizzle - Karahui & Blue Earth Estate
events.venue: Karahui Wine Bar & Eatery, 1 Memorial Square, Martinborough
events.description:
Each oil will be paired with small, thoughtfully prepared tasting dishes from Karahui that draw from Asian culinary traditions—designed to highlight unexpected yet compelling flavour combinations.
Karahui Wine Bar & Restaurant will host a collaborative tasting evening with Blue Earth Estate, highlighting the versatility of locally produced olive oil and wine alongside bold, umami-driven Asian cuisine.
The event will include a guided olive oil tasting featuring Blue Earth’s extra virgin oils, paired with a custom-designed tasting menu from Karahui that explores how Asian flavours interact with olive oil.
The experience will conclude with a wine flight from Blue Earth, showcasing thoughtful pairings that complement the dishes.
The focus is on education and enjoyment, celebrating local producers while introducing guests to unique cross-cultural flavour pairings in a relaxed, shared setting.

events.description:
Contestants of 'It's in the Bag' become political candidates in 'It's in the Ballot' Meet the Candidates.
Candidates choose a numbered box which has a question that has been submitted online by voters before the show.
It’s in the Ballot” is a community-led awareness and participation initiative.

events.venue: A Duncan Street Wellington, Wellington Region
events.description:
Vocal FX is a group spanning over 20 years of growth, success, and change.
This concert is inspired by the themes of the 2025 National Barbershop Convention He Awa Whiria, weaving the braids of connection within our barbershop community like a river braid.
Throughout its history, Vocal FX has sewn threads of connection far and wide; we plan to highlight some of these relationships across the evening, while acknowledging the changes we are making to who we are, from within.
This concert will feature songs acknowledging the past, recognising new beginnings, and looking into the future, with who we strive to become.
Thank you to everyone new and old on this journey with us, we are looking forward to performing with, and for, all of you.

events.name: NZTrio presents Fantastique
events.venue: St Andrews on the Terrace, 30 The Terrace, Wellington
events.description:
Described as a “national treasure” and “New Zealand’s most indispensable ensemble”, NZTrio He Taonga Wairere is renowned for its eclectic repertoire, outstanding talent and warm kiwi stage presence.
Bringing together three incredibly accomplished artists: Amalia Hall (violin), Callum Hall (guest cello) and Somi Kim (piano), every NZTrio performance powerfully reaffirms the importance and cathartic nature of a live musical experience in today’s digital world.
Chen Yi's Tibetan Tunes creates a fusion of traditional Tibetan melodies referencing Buddhist god Du Mu, before the premiere of Angelus, a new commission by one of Aotearoa’s most acclaimed composers, John Psathas.
1 in F sharp minor is as charming and intimate as it is powerful and explosive.
The programme Joaquín Turina | Circulo Shostakovich | Piano Trio No.1 in C minor Chen Yi | Tibetan Tunes John Psathas | Angelus César Franck | Piano Trio No.1 in F sharp minor Companion tickets available

events.long_description: For one morning only – Loosie’s Superette is opening for breakfast, serving a comfort-filled menu with banging tunes and endless caffeine. Think trayfuls of fluffy pancakes, bacon and egg muffins, crispy hash browns drowned in maple syrup, and bottomless drip coffee to keep things rolling. Add a cheeky mimosa or two, and you’ve got the perfect start to your weekend. Whether you’re with your brunch crew, shaking off a hangover, or chasing the crispy bits, this is a morning made for indulgence. It’s all about good food, loud laughs, and that first sip of something strong with your best mates by your side. No rules, no rush - just tunes pumping, trays piling up, and that warm, familiar feeling of a proper brunch done right.

events.id: We 💛 Mac 'n' Cheese-Everybody Eats at LTD., 60 Dixon St-WOAP
events.name: We 💛 Mac 'n' Cheese
events.venue: Everybody Eats at LTD., 60 Dixon St
events.long_description:
A feast with purpose, where every bowl makes a difference.
Celebrate the final day of Visa Wellington On a Plate and the end of winter with the ultimate comfort food: mac 'n' cheese, served all day long.

Two of Wellington’s legendary food rescue and community dining champions, Everybody Eats and Kaibosh, are joining forces to serve piping hot mac 'n' cheese, raising funds to help feed the community. As official charity partners of the festival, they are turning comfort food into real impact.

For just $10, each bowl will help fund a three-course meal for someone in need through Everybody Eats or provide a day’s worth of food for a family via Kaibosh.

Customise your mac with a range of toppings and flavours, all made from rescued food, showcasing just how delicious food recovery can be. In the lead-up to the event, Everybody Eats and Kaibosh will be calling on their social media followers to share their favourite mac 'n' cheese combos, with the top picks featured on the day.

Diners can enjoy their meal seated in the Everybody Eats restaurant or opt for takeaway to share with the whānau or flat.

The goal is to serve 2,000 bowls and fund 2,000 meals for the community. Join the celebration, enjoy incredible kai and help make a real difference.

events.id: Love Language-Lustre Kitchen and Dining, 7-13 Seaview Road-WOAP
events.name: Love Language
events.venue: Lustre Kitchen and Dining, 7-13 Seaview Road
events.long_description:
Calling budding poets and hopeless romantics - this is your opportunity to share your love of language, with a food and poetry degustation. 
This four-course dinner is a physical manifestation of love and an ode to food. Join Simon Sweetman, Wellington writer, critic, musician and poet, as he reads some of his own poetry, and yours too if you're feeling game. Chefs Tim and Aaron Banks will lovingly create a four-course dinner with ingredients locally sourced and lovingly produced by small scale sustainable farmers... and perhaps they will read their own poems too. 
If you're feeling poetic bring along your own poem specially crafted around this year's festival theme 'Food is Love'. It can be as long or short as you like, as happy or sad, comical or tragic, Keats or Bukowski. Spot prizes for various categories including 'Most Related to the Theme' and 'Most Obviously Foodie' poems. Includes four courses, and a welcome glass of bubbles on arrival.

events.venue: Inverlochy Art School, Wellington
events.description:
IAS Cushion Concerts presents local bands in the intimate environment of historic Inverlochy House.
This August join us for 'songs of road trips, relationships and reality tv' with Buffalo, Buffalo, Buffalo.
This seven-piece herd of instrument addicts play a mix of electronic and acoustic to produce pop-rock that is equal parts playful, whimsical and catchy.
The group have been playing together for two years and have an EP on the way.
Free entry for tamariki and no worries if cushion's aren't your thing - we have chairs!

events.id: Nota Bene and The Bach Choir of Wellington - Quiz Night-1852 Pub & Kitchen, 55 Cleveland St, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Nota Bene and The Bach Choir of Wellington - Quiz Night
events.venue: 1852 Pub & Kitchen, 55 Cleveland St, Wellington
events.long_description:
Nota Bene and The Bach Choir combine for a quiz night fundraiser to be held at the 1852 pub in Brooklyn on Sunday 31st August .

Please, invite friends, form winning teams in advance but remember you can also just build a team on the night with unaligned quizzers. Such randomly formed teams are great fun and have won on previous occasions.

The Quiz proper starts at 7pm but you can also have dinner there from 5pm by calling 1852 in advance and making a booking (04 801 9544)

This is the first opportuity for the two choir collaboration, and our Chamber orchestra Chiesa Ensemble to get together as we start rehearals leading to a performance of the masterwork, Weihnachts Oratorium (Bachs's XMAS Oratorio).

That concert will happen at 7pm on the 15th of November at St Mary of the Angels.

events.id: It's in the Ballot - WCC – Paekawakawa/Southern General Ward -In-studio- Hutchison Road Wellington, Wellington Region-Event Brite
events.name: It's in the Ballot - WCC – Paekawakawa/Southern General Ward -In-studio
events.venue: Hutchison Road Wellington, Wellington Region
events.description:
Contestants of 'It's in the Bag' become political candidates in 'It's in the Ballot' Meet the Candidates.
Candidates choose a numbered box which has a question that has been submitted online by voters before the show.
It’s in the Ballot” is a community-led awareness and participation initiative.
We aim to increase voter interest in the general and council elections nationally.
By using broadcasting and web-based technologies to deliver in-studio; online on Facebook, YouTube and Twitch; and edited as YouTube videos we aim to enable voters to make informed voting decisions.

events.id: Rockshop Bandquest - Wellington Day 2-Sacred Heart College, 65 Laings Road, Lower Hutt-Event Finder
events.name: Rockshop Bandquest - Wellington Day 2
events.venue: Sacred Heart College, 65 Laings Road, Lower Hutt
events.description:
Rockshop Bandquest is Aoteaora's live music event for Primary and Intermediate aged school students.
In its fifteenth year, the programme annually hosts hundreds of young bands in venues throughout the country.
Presented by the Wright Family Foundation, and powered by NZ Rockshop, the programme is run by RQP Group (Rockquest Promotions) - the team behind Smokefreerockquest, Smokefree Tangata Beats, and Showquest performing arts competitions.
We are holding two event days for the Wellington region, please make sure you are buying tickets for the correct day!
The schools scheduled to compete on this day are listed below: Brooklyn Primary School Evans Bay Intermediate Newlands Intermediate Scots College South Wellington Intermediate School Wadestown School

events.name: Bad Kitty Cabaret: Live Long & Prosper
events.venue: The Fringe Bar, 26 Allen Street, Wellington
events.description:
Prepare to get beamed up by our fabulous range of Sci Fi babes.
From Trekkies to Star Warriors and Jed Heads, our latest Bad Kitty show will be sure to go where no man has gone before!
Featuring Teruminator & Tiger Fury, The Golden Diamonds, Violet Spice, Marlequin, Red Queens, Lavinia Lovestruck, Maximum Clownage, Lulabelle Star, Hunnybi, Lola Brunelle, Rocky Rhodes, Elisa, Rachael, Mel Teasr, Anna Ashton & Dylan Daisy with emcee Violet Sazarec.
Bad Kitty Cabaret is a show for up-and-coming performers as well as experienced guests in pole, burlesque, drag and circus.

events.id: Paediatrics: Daytime Mobility & Function + Practical Workshop (Nelson)- Saxton Road, Stoke, Nelson Nelson, Nelson Region-Event Brite
events.name: Paediatrics: Daytime Mobility & Function + Practical Workshop (Nelson)
events.venue: Saxton Road, Stoke, Nelson Nelson, Nelson Region
events.description:
Powerchair Academy Nelson - Venue to be announced _____________________________________________________________________________________________ Overview: Join us for an engaging and interactive session focused on paediatric Assistive Technology (AT) and safe car seat solutions!
We’ll explore prescribing AT for sitting, standing, stepping, and mobility—blending clinical theory with real-world insights on equipment choices.
Engage in a hands-on practical session to test techniques, plus learn how to collaborate with parents, caregivers, and kids for practical, daily-use solutions, including safe transportation.
Learning Objectives Identify and describe different types of paediatric Assistive Technology (AT) equipment Explain the clinical rationale behind equipment prescription Enhance collaboration with families and caregivers Assess the functional needs of children and recommend suitable AT solutions About our Presentor: Jamie's Bio: BSc Physiotheraop, Paediatric Product Education - Medifab Jamie Cockle is a trained physiotherapist and Medifab's Paediatric Clinical Educator and Seating and Positioning Specialist.
With a passion for empowering therapists, product specialists, and families, Jamie provides expert training on Medifab’s paediatric equipment, ensuring practical knowledge that can be applied every day to optimise children’s health and happiness.

events.id: Writers on Mondays: The Conditions of Rapture-Te Marae, Te Papa Tongarewa, 55 Cable Street, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Writers on Mondays: The Conditions of Rapture
events.venue: Te Marae, Te Papa Tongarewa, 55 Cable Street, Wellington
events.description:
The Conditions of Rapture: Amy Marguerite, Sophie Van Waardenberg, and Emma Barnes Three extraordinary poets introduce their new collections, books of poetry brimming over with feeling and taut with intellectual curiosity.
Amy Marguerite (over under fed), Sophie van Waardenberg (No Good), and Emma Barnes (if we knew how to we would) talk with Anna Jackson about the conditionality of rapture, the loveliness of loneliness, the difficulty of living in a hungry body, and how it has felt to keep writing through a pandemic, heartbreak and grief, and why it matters to make space for metaphor and memory, for sparrows and bees and a guinea-pig, eating a dandelion, its mouth full of gold.
Admission Is Free—all Welcome Writers on Mondays is presented with the Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa, Circa Theatre, Meow and Phantom Billstickers National Poetry Day and supported by the Letteri Family.

events.id: Echoes of Home - A Musical Journey Across Time-24 Kelburn Pde, Kelburn, Wellington 6012, New Zealand-Facebook
events.name: Echoes of Home - A Musical Journey Across Time
events.venue: 24 Kelburn Pde, Kelburn, Wellington 6012, New Zealand
events.long_description:
(Ticket Required)
Tuesday , 2 September 2025
Doors open: 4:30 PM | Performance begins: 5:15 PM sharp
Hunter Council Chamber, Hunter Building, Kelburn Parade, Wellington
Free Entry | All Welcome
In celebration of 80 years of Vietnam’s National Day (2/9), join us for a powerful evening of music, memory, and connection.
Through traditional and contemporary Vietnamese songs, Echoes of Home takes you on a heartfelt journey — honouring the past, embracing the present, and looking to the future. Performed by a diverse group of community members, this special event celebrates identity, culture, and the spirit of resilience.
What to expect:
• A beautifully curated musical programme honouring Vietnam’s story
• Performances of folk and modern Vietnamese music
• Dance, piano, harp, pipa, guitar, and more
• Multilingual storytelling to connect all audiences
• A welcoming, cross-cultural experience for all backgrounds
Please note: Doors close at 5:15 PM for the stage programme. No entry will be permitted during performances.
With thanks to our generous supporters:
MAY Coffee Crew • Hell Pizza • First National Real Estate Collective • Bellagio Cafe & Spa • Fabulash Brows & Beauty • Hutt City FM • Hi Tea • Golden Pine Trading Ltd • Saigon Xin Chao • Hutt City FM 106.7!
Hosted by Viet Hub NZ — rooted in culture, powered by community.
Follow this page for more updates

events.id: Botany Tours for Conservation Week at Te Papa-55 Cable Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Botany Tours for Conservation Week at Te Papa
events.venue: 55 Cable Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Come behind the scenes to visit the Botany collection which houses more than 300,000 plant specimens collected in Aotearoa New Zealand and overseas.
There are two tours available:
Tuesday 2nd September BOH 11.30 – 12.30pm
Thursday 4th September BOH 3.30 – 4.30PM
You will find out how we store and take care of these valuable collections, and the research they support. There will be a chance to see our precious botanical taonga, including botanical specimens and art, and have a closer look at the very first plants collected by the European naturalists Joseph Banks and Daniel Solander over 250 years ago during Captain James Cook’s first voyage to New Zealand.

events.id: Women in finance lunch, with speaker Christina Leung, CFA- Lambton Quay Wellington, North Island-Event Brite
events.name: Women in finance lunch, with speaker Christina Leung, CFA
events.venue: Lambton Quay Wellington, North Island
events.long_description:
Welcome to the Women in Finance Lunch event! Join us for an inspiring talk by Christina Leung, CFA at Forsyth Barr. This in-person event will bring together women in the finance industry to network, learn, and empower each other. Don't miss this opportunity to hear from a successful professional and connect with like-minded individuals. Reserve your spot now!
We're pleased to invite our members and CFA candidates to another Women in Finance lunch, this time with guest speaker; CFA charterholder, Christina Leung, CFA, Deputy Chief Executive & Principal Economist, NZIER
About our presenter
Christina Leung, CFA is Vice Chair of the CFA Society New Zealand and Deputy Chief Executive (Auckland) and Principal Economist at the NZ Institute of Economic Research (NZIER), where she looks after economic forecasts and analysis of the Quarterly Survey of Business Opinion. Christina also works with many clients looking at topical issues, including the wider economic impact of particular industries and investments. She previously worked at the Reserve Bank of New Zealand and ASB. Christina holds a Bachelor of Commerce with first class honours in Economics.
Christina will talk about her career journey and share her experiences of being a woman in the world of economics and finance.
Bring a friend
We invite members and candidates to bring along a colleague, please register for catering purposes.
Men are very welcome too!
As with previous events, we understand you're busy. It's okay to arrive late, or leave early, we'd just like to see you.
Many thanks to Forsyth Barr for hosting this event.

events.id: Healthy Hospo Building Resilience Christchurch-456 Papanui Road, Christchurch-Humanitix
events.name: Healthy Hospo Building Resilience Christchurch
events.venue: 456 Papanui Road, Christchurch
events.description:
Why this matters: In our rapidly changing world, resilience emerges as a fundamental skill.
Resilience enables individuals to navigate uncertainty with confidence and adaptability.
This 90-minute workshop delves into the profound significance of resilience, offering participants practical insights and actionable strategies to cultivate resilience and harness the potential of the mind.
By equipping individuals with these tools, the workshop empowers them to not only weather storms but also thrive in dynamic environments.
Sarah is motivated to continue creating positive change and to educate people about the power of the mind and how to use life's challenges as an opportunity for growth.

events.id: Wellington Climate Fresk Workshop-57 Willis Street, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Wellington Climate Fresk Workshop
events.venue: 57 Willis Street, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Do you want to be part of the solution to tackle climate change but don’t have the time to become a climate scientist? Join us for a 3-hour interactive workshop to explore the causes and consequences of climate disturbances.
Based on the IPCC report and played by over 2 million people worldwide, this collaborative workshop allows you to understand the key issues of climate change to empower you to take action.
How it works:
The workshop is based on a 42-card game. Each card represents an element, a cause or a consequence of climate change.
In teams, guided by your facilitator, you are encouraged to find the cause-effect relationship between the different components of climate change. Collective intelligence will get you from one deck of card to the next!
This step-by-step reconstruction provides keys to understand the complexity and develop an overview of climate change.
Agenda:
Introduction, 15 mins
Fresk Card Game, 1 1/2 hours
Debrief and Actions, 1 hour 15 mins
Climate Fresk is an excellent opportunity to understand the key elements of climate change and what you can do to be part of the solution. No previous climate knowledge is needed.

Tea, coffee and snacks will be served during the short break. Workshop run by Climate Training Co. Ltd. Donations welcome!
events.description:

events.id: Echoes of Home: A Musical Journey Across Time-Kelburn Parade Wellington, Wellington Region-Event Brite
events.name: Echoes of Home: A Musical Journey Across Time
events.venue: Kelburn Parade Wellington, Wellington Region
events.long_description:
Event Information
Some days remind us who we are and where we come from — when an entire nation moves as one to honour Independence.
To celebrate the 80th Anniversary of Vietnam’s National Day (2 September), Viet Hub NZ proudly presents
“Echoes of Home – A Musical Across Time”
This free concert is a heartfelt journey through the sounds of Vietnamese history — from nostalgic childhood songs to powerful wartime ballads and modern melodies of pride and hope. All performances will include English subtitles, making it easy for everyone to follow along and connect with the stories.
Whether you’re Vietnamese or simply curious about a different culture, this is a wonderful opportunity to experience the warmth, resilience, and beauty of Vietnam through music and storytelling.
🎁 Raffle with Over $300 in Prizes
Don’t miss our special raffle on the day. Tickets will be available at the venue for $5 and $10. Payment can be made in cash or by bank transfer.
💛 Support Viet Hub NZ
This event is free to attend, but if you believe in what we do and want to help us continue running community workshops, cultural events, and youth-led initiatives — please consider making a donation.
👉 Donate here: https://givealittle.co.nz/cause/viet-hub-nz-rooted-in-culture-powered-by-community
Your koha helps keep our work going, rooted in culture, powered by community.

All performances will include English subtitles, making it easy for everyone to follow along and connect with the stories.

events.id: Book Group: Heart of A Dog By Mikhail Bulgakov-The Library, 1/53 Courtenay Place, Te Aro, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Book Group: Heart of A Dog By Mikhail Bulgakov
events.venue: The Library, 1/53 Courtenay Place, Te Aro, Wellington
events.long_description:
Wellington Classic Literature Group meets on the first Tuesday of the month. We read novels that have stood the test of time, whether they were written in 1780, 1880 or even 1980. It's a public group so feel free to come along when it suits.

Our September book is Heart of a Dog (or A Dog's Heart), a 1925 novel by Mikhail Bulgakov, described as a biting satire of Bolshevism. The book wasn't officially published in the Soviet Union until 1987.

Our group very much enjoyed Bulgakov's masterpiece The Master and Margarita back in 2018, so looking forward to reading another of his works...

VENUE
We meet in the ‘Games Room’, The Library bar's private area overlooking Courtenay Place. After you enter the bar, head to your right (up the step) and through a smaller space with booths to the large carpeted space beyond.

events.id: Cooking: Gourmet Sausage Making-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
events.name: Cooking: Gourmet Sausage Making
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Cooking: Gourmet Sausage Making Come along and learn how to fill sausage casings with a tasty mincemeat and get tips and tricks on how to make your own customized sausage mixes at home with the use of various herbs and spices.
Everyone will get some sausages to take home and enjoy.
All ingredients included in course fee but please bring your apron, a dish cloth and a couple of tea towels to the session.
By the end of the course, you’ll be able to: -  Recognise how to handle a knife safely -  Understand food safety and hygiene around sausage-making and avoiding cross contamination -  Recognise the difference between two kinds of sausage casings and why you use each of them -  Have some ideas on how to make and cook a good quality sausage properly -  Be able to safely store sausages products Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel.
We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly.

events.id: Paediatrics: Daytime Mobility & Function + Practical Workshop (Wellington)- Stewart Duff Drive Wellington, Wellington Region-Event Brite
events.name: Paediatrics: Daytime Mobility & Function + Practical Workshop (Wellington)
events.venue: Stewart Duff Drive Wellington, Wellington Region
events.long_description:
Paediatric Academy Wellington - Venue to be announced
_____________________________________________________________________________________________
Overview:
Join us for an engaging and interactive session focused on paediatric Assistive Technology (AT) and safe car seat solutions! We’ll explore prescribing AT for sitting, standing, stepping, and mobility—blending clinical theory with real-world insights on equipment choices.
Engage in a hands-on practical session to test techniques, plus learn how to collaborate with parents, caregivers, and kids for practical, daily-use solutions, including safe transportation. Don’t miss this chance to boost your skills and confidence!
Learning Objectives
Identify and describe different types of paediatric Assistive Technology (AT) equipment
Explain the clinical rationale behind equipment prescription
Enhance collaboration with families and caregivers
Assess the functional needs of children and recommend suitable AT solutions
About our Presentor:
Jamie's Bio:
BSc Physiotheraop, Paediatric Product Education - Medifab
Jamie Cockle is a trained physiotherapist and Medifab's Paediatric Clinical Educator and Seating and Positioning Specialist. With a passion for empowering therapists, product specialists, and families, Jamie provides expert training on Medifab’s paediatric equipment, ensuring practical knowledge that can be applied every day to optimise children’s health and happiness.
Jamie’s career began as a Paediatric Physiotherapist at Noah’s Ark Children’s Hospital in Cardiff, followed by a role at Bristol Royal Hospital for Children. It was in these settings that he developed his expertise in paediatric equipment, particularly for children with neurological conditions. He is driven by the belief that every child should have access to the right support, regardless of their abilities or diagnosis..

events.id: Amanda Bunting and Kris Zuelicke, Solos and Duets for Piano-St Marks Church Lower Hutt, 58 Woburn Road, Lower Hutt-Event Finder
events.name: Amanda Bunting and Kris Zuelicke, Solos and Duets for Piano
events.venue: St Marks Church Lower Hutt, 58 Woburn Road, Lower Hutt
events.long_description:
Leo Smit - Divertimento

Ginastera - No. 2 from Danzas Argentinas, op. 2 - "Danza de la moza donosa"

Ravel - Sonatine, M. 40, Movement I - Modéré

Schubert - "Lebensstürme," Allegro in A minor, D 947

Amanda Bunting is a graduate of the New Zealand School of Music, completing her Bachelor of Music with Honours in 2019 in solo piano performance with Dr. Jian Liu; small group ensemble with Dr. Rolf Gjelsten; and performance and embodiment studies with Dr. Hamish Robb and Dr. Margaret Medlyn. Prior to that, she completed a Graduate Diploma in Music in performance piano, performance studies, and pedagogy.

After previously studying with Gillian Bibby at the Conservatorium of Music and graduating in 1996, Amanda chose to return to study to further develop performance skills, enhance her own piano performance abilities and to gain further knowledge that can be shared with her piano students. Amanda is an Associate of the Institute of Registered Music Teachers New Zealand, a member of the Wellington Branch and currently works both as a Piano Teacher and a Human Resources Adviser at Victoria University of Wellington.

Kris Zuelicke grew up in a theatrical and musical family, accompanying shows and choirs from high school onwards. In the USA, she gained degrees in Music (BA Miami University) and Music Theory (MA Indiana University) and taught music along with other subjects at the Bloomington Montessori School.

In Karlsruhe, Germany Kris taught at the Landau Montessori School, Berlitz Language School, courses on theatre and music at the Teacher’s College and piano privately. She studied with Annemi Egri and Sariel Maler during this time.

Kris currently teaches in five schools around Wellington, maintains a thriving private piano and cello studio and accompanies students at the New Zealand School of Music. Her most recent degree is in harpsichord performance (DMA NZSM), including study and research in Boston with Mark Kroll. Kris enjoys performing regularly with other musicians, including piano duets, chamber music and has enjoyed projects with Stroma, the Queen’s Closet and a fun stint as a harpsichordist extra in the recently released Time Bandits.

2 - "Danza de la moza donosa" Ravel - Sonatine, M. 40, Movement I - Modéré Schubert - "Lebensstürme," Allegro in A minor, D 947 Amanda Bunting is a graduate of the New Zealand School of Music, completing her Bachelor of Music with Honours in 2019 in solo piano performance with Dr. Jian Liu; small group ensemble with Dr. Rolf Gjelsten; and performance and embodiment studies with Dr. Hamish Robb and Dr. Margaret Medlyn.

events.id: The Racket Lounge: Session Three-Bedlam and Squalor, Upstairs, 18 Garrett Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: The Racket Lounge: Session Three
events.venue: Bedlam and Squalor, Upstairs, 18 Garrett Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.long_description:
Grab a spot on our couch and enjoy the noise at The Racket Lounge, a chill classical music series featuring up-and-coming Pōneke classical and jazz musicians.

Last year the NZSQ Trust launched the Racket Lounge, a concert series for classical and jazz musicians with experience ranging from students to pros to freely express their creativity in a non-traditional concert setting. It was a huge success, with over 250 audience members and 52 artists over our four sessions. Audiences were raving about the musical variety and great talent they found at the Racket Lounge, and as one audience member commented; “Well done…do it again!” So, we listened, and the Racket Lounge is back for round two! Once again hosted at Bedlam & Squalor (above the Rogue & Vagabond), we welcome audiences, composers and performers back for another four concerts full of innovative, fun, and chill music. From classical to pop covers, video game soundtracks to original compositions, there's something for everyone to sink their teeth into at The Racket Lounge!

Even if you've never been to a classical music concert before, this one is for you. With a 'Choose your price' model you can afford to give it a go - and you might even find something you like!

A Flexible Price, So You Can Take A Chance on Something New:
Our prices range from $5 to $100, just pick the ticket price you feel like paying. At The Racket Lounge, we believe everyone should have access to high-quality but affordable art. If you're a bit strapped for cash right now, but still want a good night out, no worries! Just book yourself a $5 ticket! If you can afford to pay a little more and want to do some good for your community, then pick one of our higher ticket prices and rest assured that your dollars are going towards funding great, accessible art in your city.

All proceeds from ticket sales will go directly into presenting the next Racket Lounge, including paying musicians and artists, hiring instruments and marketing costs. Plus, by choosing a higher price point, you're ensuring that we're able to continue to offer tickets at a lower price point for those who need it.

Please note: Bedlam & Squalor is a licenced venue, so under 18s must be accompanied by a parent or legal guardian. Everyone must bring ID.

events.id: Integrating Creative Writing Into Painting - 4 Week Course-Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Integrating Creative Writing Into Painting - 4 Week Course
events.venue: Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington
events.long_description:
Creative writing and painting are both powerful forms of artistic expression. By integrating creative writing into your painting practice, you can enhance your imagination, storytelling abilities, emotional expression, attention to detail, and personal style on the canvas. Please bring along a journal or laptop.

COURSE CONTENT
Each session presents a key idea backed by research or concrete examples, followed by practical writing exercises with optional sharing. We learn by doing and from each other.

1. Generating work from the interior: tapping into memories, conflict, emotion, and observation to generate art.
2. Figuring out what matters to you, then learning how to grow your fragmented ideas into something whole. For example, how do you turn a feeling, or a fleeting moment in time into a story? Into a painting? Into a work of art? What are the building blocks you need?
3. Inspiration from other creative sources: people, music, poetry, reading, random incidents. Ways to generate fresh ideas. How to clarify and focus in writing and art.
4. Structure and boundaries. Dreaming big but being real. How do you find and stick to a creative process? Understanding how you learn and what kind of feedback you need. Designing your next project.

Thursday mornings, 9:30 - 11:45 am.
4 - 25 September.
events.description:
By integrating creative writing into your painting practice, you can enhance your imagination, storytelling abilities, emotional expression, attention to detail, and personal style on the canvas.
We learn by doing and from each other.
Figuring out what matters to you, then learning how to grow your fragmented ideas into something whole.
Into a painting?
How to clarify and focus in writing and art.

events.id: It's in the Ballot - CDC – Carterton Councilor at Large -In-studio-117 Chester Rd, Clareville, Carterton Clareville, Wellington Region 5791-Event Brite
events.name: It's in the Ballot - CDC – Carterton Councilor at Large -In-studio
events.venue: 117 Chester Rd, Clareville, Carterton Clareville, Wellington Region 5791
events.long_description:
Contestants of 'It's in the Bag' become political candidates in 'It's in the Ballot' Meet the Candidates.
Candidates choose a numbered box which has a question that has been submitted online by voters before the show.
It’s in the Ballot” is a community-led awareness and participation initiative. We aim to increase voter interest in the general and council elections nationally.
By using broadcasting and web-based technologies to deliver in-studio; online on Facebook, YouTube and Twitch; and edited as YouTube videos we aim to enable voters to make informed voting decisions.
This means you can send the weblink of the YouTube Video of your electorate show to your friends and whanau to encourage them to watch the show before they cast their votes.
Voting papers are sent to voters on Tuesday 9th September 2025 and must be delivered into a voting dropbox by 12pm Saturday 11th October 2025

events.id: Taiwan’s Economic Statecraft and the future of Liberal International Order-28 Kelburn Parade Wellington, Wellington Region 6012-Event Brite
events.name: Taiwan’s Economic Statecraft and the future of Liberal International Order
events.venue: 28 Kelburn Parade Wellington, Wellington Region 6012
events.long_description:
Abstract
Over the last decade, China has punished countries that undermine its territorial claims and foreign policy goals with measures such as restricting trade, encouraging popular boycotts, and cutting off tourism. These coercive measures have caused significant economic damage to U.S. partners such as Japan, the Philippines, Taiwan, and Australia. This talk focuses on Taiwan’s response to China’s economic sanctions, highlighting the agency of medium-sized countries in the shadow of a great power.
The second part of this presentation will propose a common understanding of the liberal international order in which state and non-state actors follow rules, norms, and legal procedures in conducting international affairs. This rule-based practice is an essential part of the Asian regional order. If Taiwan were integrated into the multilateral institutions in Asia, the chance of conflict would be greatly reduced. The future of Taiwan also depends on the resilience of the liberal international order and other middle-power states in the Asia Pacific.
Bio
Christina Lai is an Associate Research Fellow in the Institute of Political Science at Academia Sinica, Taiwan. Dr. Lai received her Ph.D. in Government from Georgetown University. In 2015-2016, she was a post-doctoral fellow in China and the World Program at Princeton University. She is interested in U.S.-China-Taiwan Relations, Chinese Foreign Policy, East Asian politics, and Qualitative Research Methods. Her works have appeared in the Politics, International Politics, Political Science, PS: Political Science & Politics, Journal of Contemporary China, Pacific Review, and Asian Security.

events.name: Sound Healing Experience
events.venue: 175 Vivian Street #Level 1 Wellington, Wellington 6011
events.long_description:
Sound Healing Experience
It’ll be a transcendent evening of Sacred Harmonic Sounds, where multi-instrumentalist Claudio Escutia will guide you through a deeply restorative sonic experience. Plus - there will be an amazing plant-based dinner & dessert included in your ticket!
Let the vibrations of Gongs, Crystal and Tibetan singing bowls, Native American flutes, and other ancient instruments wash over you—melting away tension, quieting the mind, and opening a doorway to inner stillness.
With Claudio’s masterful soundscapes, you’ll not only hear the music but feel it resonating through your body, inviting profound relaxation and a reconnection to your heart. No prior meditation or yoga experience is needed—just come as you are and let the sound carry you into a space of deep peace.
What to Bring?Yoga mats, blankets & cushions are provided but you are also welcome to bring your own yoga mat and any extra cushions or any other comforts for the ultimate experience!
Why You Won’t Want to Miss This
A rare opportunity to experience Claudio’s unique fusion of world music traditions and healing sound
A deeply immersive, meditative experience—perfect for relaxation and renewal
Limited spaces
Event followed by a plant-based dinner and dessert, all included in your ticket!
Meet Your Host: Claudio Escutia
Born into a musical family in Mexico City, Claudio’s lifelong passion for sound has taken him across the globe—from studying jazz in Montreal to mastering Tibetan singing bowls in Kathmandu. His music weaves together classical training, world instruments (Sitar, Esraj, Harmonium, and more), and a deep reverence for sound as medicine.
Ready to unwind and recharge through the magic of vibration?
Learn more or listen to Claudio’s music here:
SoundCloud: Claudio EscutiaInstagram: Claudio Escutia Yoga and Sound Healing (@claudio_yoga_sound_healing)Facebook: Claudio Escutia Yoga - Sound Healing- Music

events.id: A free workshop for the General Public: Dying to Know about Dying Matters?-331 Suffolk Road Nelson, Nelson 7011-Event Brite
events.name: A free workshop for the General Public: Dying to Know about Dying Matters?
events.venue: 331 Suffolk Road Nelson, Nelson 7011
events.long_description:
Please note, this is a FREE workshop availble to the public and is not designed for health professionals to attend.
Many people find it difficult to talk about dying, yet dying is an important stage of life and is inevitable.
We plan for the birth of a child, yet when it comes to the end of life, we don’t often want to think , or talk about it.
Come along to our workshop and find out more about dying matters, how an Advance Care Planning (ACP)can benefit you and your family/whānau and what to expect at the end of life.
Having a plan outlines our care preferences for the future. Having an Advance Care Plan (ACP) that aligns with our beliefs and values, is a gift that we can give to our family / whānau.
We will explore:
Why is it hard to talk about death and dying?
What to expect when someone is dying
Supports available
Advance care planning processes
Date: Friday 5 September 2025
Time: 9.00 am - 12.30 pm
Presenters: Mary Ann Hardcastle Advance Care Plannining Facilitator & Chris Dunn Clinical Nurse Educator Nelson Tasman Hospice
Cost: Free
Limited attendees: Registration is essential
Who can attend?: General Public (This workshop is not designed for Health Professionals)
Venue: Nelson Tasman Hospice, 331 Suffolk Road, Stoke, Nelson

events.id: 2025 Taiwan Update Lectures-Kelburn Parade Wellington, Wellington Region 6012-Event Brite
events.name: 2025 Taiwan Update Lectures
events.venue: Kelburn Parade Wellington, Wellington Region 6012
events.long_description:
Taiwan’s Multidimensional Energy Security Challenges
Professor Chyungly Lee
A stable and reliable energy supply is essential for a nation’s economic growth and development. In selecting fuel sources, nowadays almost all countries have taken climate change into account, adopted sensible clean energy transition plans, and designed a schedule to meet the goal of Net Zero. While pursuing a 3-E (energy-economic-environmental) balanced energy supply strategy, Taiwan, lacking indigenous resources, faces unique challenges of supply disruptions from over dependence on energy imports and possible blockade, quarantine, or invasion from Beijing. Any disruption of power supply or surge of energy costs could not only threaten Taiwan’s competitive edge in the global high-tech market but also undermine Taiwan’s internal stability and the nation’s survival. In this talk, Dr. Chyungly Lee will first present fact sheets on Taiwan’s energy status, summarize Taiwan’s current energy strategy, and then discuss dilemmas and vulnerabilities that Taiwan might face in the next few years.
What does Taiwan’s two-level politics tell us?
Professor Alex Tan
This presentation examines Taiwan as a critical case study for understanding the evolving challenges to democracy in the 21st century. Arguing that Taiwan serves as a “canary in the coalmine,” the analysis highlights how the island’s early and persistent political polarization—rooted in identity politics and the legacies of authoritarian rule—prefigures trends now visible in established democracies worldwide. The research explores how deep divisions between the Kuomintang (KMT) and Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), reinforced by institutional and social factors, have led to legislative gridlock, declining trust in political institutions, and a “democratic ceiling” that constrains further democratic development. Taiwan’s precarious geopolitical position, facing constant pressure from the People’s Republic of China, intensifies the dilemma of balancing national security with the protection of civil liberties. The presentation analyzes Taiwan’s innovative responses to disinformation, foreign interference, and public health crises, illustrating both the resilience and fragility of democratic systems under external and internal stress.
Gaming Taiwan: Indigenous Epistemologies in Play
Associate Professor Chia-rong Wu
This research explores how Indigenous knowledge systems in Taiwan are being revitalized through video games. Far from mere entertainment, these games draw on tribal traditions, ancestral stories, and deep connections to the land to create meaningful digital experiences. By blending oral storytelling with interactive gameplay, Taiwanese Indigenous game developers are preserving cultural memory while challenging colonial legacies. Titles like Princess Baleng, Tayal, VuVu, and Gadvia show how games can empower communities and pass down wisdom to younger generations in innovative and engaging ways. Gamers not only play a game but also immerse themselves in digital environments shaped by Indigenous perspectives and values. This study encourages all engaged audiences, including educators and students, to consider video games as powerful tools for cultural resurgence and learning. Focusing on Indigenous Taiwan, it highlights how digital games integrate historical consciousness and interactivity to reimagine the past and future of the island.

In selecting fuel sources, nowadays almost all countries have taken climate change into account, adopted sensible clean energy transition plans, and designed a schedule to meet the goal of Net Zero.
Any disruption of power supply or surge of energy costs could not only threaten Taiwan’s competitive edge in the global high-tech market but also undermine Taiwan’s internal stability and the nation’s survival.
What does Taiwan’s two-level politics tell us?
Professor Alex Tan This presentation examines Taiwan as a critical case study for understanding the evolving challenges to democracy in the 21st century.

events.id: 'WOMB WOMEN' Workshop for Women-65 Dixon Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: 'WOMB WOMEN' Workshop for Women
events.venue: 65 Dixon Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
IMAGINE...100 THOUSAND GRANDMOTHERS SPANNING BACK THROUGH 2.5 MILLION YEARS OF HUMANITY. ONE WOMAN GIVING BIRTH TO THE NEXT, ON AND ON THROUGH TIME, UNTIL HERE AND NOW.

This is AN INVITATION TO COME PLAY, to create with your own hands little Womb Women in honour of your own matriarchal lineage … with hands that have been created from the DNA of all your ancestors before you.
As I sit and sculpt each woman, I become deeply aware that the bone and flesh of my own hands hold the DNA of all my grandmothers. How many of them had their own stories of shaping clay, forming sculptural figures, moulding pots .. what was it my grandmother of 200 thousand years ago created I wonder. 
Through the evolution of humanity, the hands of approximately 100 thousand womb to womb women of my unique bloodline have given birth to my own. Our shared DNA forms these hands which are now shaping clay.
Each one of us has our own special womb to womb lineage, with a unique tone particular only to us, perhaps similar to another, however no one female whakapapa is truly the same.  
Perhaps you will have a particular mother or grandmother in mind as you create, imbuing their passed down wisdom into the clay figurine, perhaps the little woman you make will symbolize your entire line, calling up the flavour of your own unique lineage, or perhaps she is you and represents your own story … or maybe she will hold for you the wisdom of the ancient mother that resides within us all. 
DO COME JOIN US for an afternoon of making your own little womb women.
NO EXPERIENCE NEEDED, simply bring a curiosity and willingness to play, surrounded by other humans doing just the same.
PRACTACALITIES,
bring a cushion and blanket (you may prefer to sit comfortably on the floor as you make - there will also be tables and chairs available)
if you are already familiar with clay and have your own favorite hand tools please feel free to bring these
snacks and hot/cold beverages will be available
Workshop cost includes supplies, materials and firing. I will fire your creation then post it back to you, therefore postage will be extra and determined once packaged up.
PLEASE NOTE!!! This booking is for FRIDAY 5TH SEPTEMBER
                                              ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
“Within the DNA is written not only our histories as individuals but the whole history of the human race … patterns of DNA that have come down to us virtually unchanged from our distant ancestors – ancestors who are no longer just an abstract entity but real people who lived in conditions very different from those we enjoy today, who survived them and brought up their children.” ~ Bryan Sykes (The Seven Daughters of Eve)
Return to MAIN EXHIBITION WEBSITE - link coming soon

events.id: Film screening: GAGA-28 Kelburn Parade Wellington, Wellington Region 6012-Event Brite
events.name: Film screening: GAGA
events.venue: 28 Kelburn Parade Wellington, Wellington Region 6012
events.long_description:
Gaga《哈勇家》(2022)
Directed by Laha Mebow 112 mins, Mandarin/Atayal/Taiwanese, English subtitles
Among the Atayal indigenous people of Taiwan, gaga is the traditional law and custom, the way of living with the land and organising society, the source of values. When Hayung, the patriarch of an Atayal family, and the senior knowledge-keeper, dies, his oldest son Payang decides to run for election as head of the local district. The film Gaga follows this election, in its raw democratic, and occasionally corrupt, form and the ways – sometimes serious, sometimes hilarious – that it affects the extended family. A groundbreaking film, Gaga is mostly in Atayal language and presents the life and social interactions of these contemporary indigenous Taiwanese people unsentimentally, with humour, with compassion, and with the sharp eye of a brilliant film-maker.
Gaga won Best Director and Best Supporting Actress at the 59th Taipei Golden Horse Film Festival in 2022. Beyond Taiwan, it won the Best Director at the 2022 Singapore International Film Festival - Asian Feature Competition and has been screened at film festivals in Hawaii, Los Angeles, Melbourne, Auckland and New York.
Q&A with Film Director Laha Mebow
We are delighted that Film Director Laha Mebow, Taiwan's first indigenous female director, will be attending the screening and take part in Q&A afterwards.
Laha Mebow is the first female director from Taiwan to win Best Director at the Golden Horse Awards, the most prestigious film award in the Chinese-speaking world. An Indigenous filmmaker of the Tayal people, she is also the first Indigenous woman in Taiwan to direct a narrative feature. Her films explore spiritual inheritance, family trauma, and Indigenous identity through a deeply personal yet cinematic lens.
She has directed three feature films. Finding Sayun (2011) reimagines a colonial-era legend from an Indigenous perspective. Lokah Laqi! (2016), a coming-of-age tale of three Indigenous boys, was selected as Taiwan’s official submission for Best Foreign Language Film at the Academy Awards. Her third feature, Gaga (2022), won Best Film at the Singapore International Film Festival and delves into generational shifts and cultural survival within an Indigenous family.
Laha’s body of work continues to break new ground for Indigenous representation in Asian cinema. Her unique voice bridges traditional storytelling and contemporary filmmaking, making her one of the most important and anticipated directors from Taiwan today.

events.name: French Film Screening - Chien de la Casse
events.venue: 78 Victoria Street Level 3 Wellington, Wellington 6011
events.long_description:
🎬 Join us for a screening of Chien de la casse (Junkyard Dog) - a gritty and quietly powerful French drama exploring friendship, masculinity, and emotional repression in a small town in France.
The plot 👉 In a sleepy village in the South of France, Dog and Mirales have been inseparable since childhood. Their bond is strong but also marked by teasing and power games - until a new arrival, Elsa, disrupts the dynamic. As Dog starts to drift toward this budding romance, Mirales is left grappling with jealousy, vulnerability, and the fear of being left behind.
The trailer 👉 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tCv83D3CQOY
Chien de la casse is a nuanced and touching debut feature by Jean-Baptiste Durand - a subtle portrait of male friendship, emotional fragility, and the unspoken tensions of rural life.
This film is rated R13 – Restricted to persons 13 years and over (Violence, offensive language, drug use & sex scenes).
📅 Friday, 05 September 2025 - 6pm
📍 Alliance Française, 78 Victoria Street, Wellington
🎥 French VO with English Subtitles
🎟️ Free entry, Koha donation

Sam Bambery is an artist and impresario from Ōtautahi/Christchurch, currently based in Naarm/Melbourne.
Exploring his love of semi-psychedelia through a twisted folk-rock lens, Bambery writes effectual and spacious songs burrowing into emotional identity and exhaustion.
His sophomore album Rubricator released in 2024 with micro-label Under Underground Records, edging at outsider-pop influence.

events.venue: Awhi Yoga and Wellbeing Centre, 15 Johnston St., Wellington
events.description:
Yoga Nidra, often referred to as "yogic sleep," is a deeply restorative practice that promotes physical relaxation, mental clarity, and emotional balance.
It's the perfect way to rejuvenate your mind, body, and soul: your hinengaro, tinana and wairua.
What to Expect: - A 90-minute guided Yoga Nidra Meditation led by one of our experienced instructors - A comfortable space to lie down (mats, blankets, bolsters & cushions provided) - A supportive community of fellow meditation enthusiasts - Complementary herbal tea before/after the session; - An opportunity to journal your experience, if desired - A chance to destress and cultivate inner calm Yoga Nidra is for everyone and no prior experience is required - everyone is welcome to experience the profound benefits of Yoga Nidra with us.
Wear comfortable clothes, and bring an open mind, a journal and eye mask if you have one (not required).
So, mark your calendar for the first Friday of each month and treat yourself to an evening of deep relaxation and mindfulness.

events.id: Jazz in Martinborough 2025-Martinborough Town Hall, 8 Texas St, Martinborough-Event Finder
events.name: Jazz in Martinborough 2025
events.venue: Martinborough Town Hall, 8 Texas St, Martinborough
events.long_description:
Big Band Brings Back the Swing
Jazz in Martinborough 2025

Jazz in Martinborough is thrilled to be bringing you the Royal New Zealand Airforce Jazz Orchestra as our feature act on Saturday at the festival for 2025.

“We’re delighted to be able to fill the stage with a full-sized big band of fabulous musicians, and the Town Hall with the fantastic sounds of the big band era,” says Jazz in Martinborough Music Director Lee Quayle.

Jazz in Martinborough is back for their 13th edition during the first weekend in September with ticketed shows on Friday 5th and Saturday 6th and other gigs around town as usual. “The RNZAF Jazz Orchestra will be one of our ticketed gigs, featuring on the Saturday evening,” says Lee. “And on Friday night we invite you to Be Transported back in time to a speak easy club with the superb swing and blues combo that is April’s Fools,” adds Lee.

Staying true to the tradition of swing and improvisation the RNZAF Jazz Orchestra draws on their own rich history dating back to the original ‘swing era’. The Orchestra is a national trailblazer in big band history and features New Zealand compositions, and a classic repertoire from the golden era of big band swing jazz of Ellington and Basie.

The band benefits from a depth of talent that most military bands around the world would only dream of and is made up of Wellington’s most exceptional musicians.

“The line-up will be a who’s who of the Wellington jazz scene,” says Lee. “It’s a while since we had a big band at the festival, so we’re elated to have the Airforce Jazz Orchestra back with us again. They last played at the festival in 2014. Many of the band members have been here since, but not as part of a big band,” says Lee.

Be Transported by April’s Fools
Imagine stepping back in time to a speak easy club. A smoky, dimly lit room where the anticipation is electric but the vibe is laid-back and relaxed. . .

From the stage a jazz swing and blues band begins to play, their instruments blending seamlessly in a harmonious symphony of sound. The rhythm section, with its upright bass and snare drums, lays down a groove that's impossible to resist, while the saxophone punctuates the air with soulful notes.

At. the forefront stands a captivating female singer, her voice rich and velvety, weaving tales of heartache, joy, and everything in between. Her vocal prowess brings both swing and blues to life, effortlessly moving from sultry, slow blues ballads to energetic, foot-tapping swing numbers.

This band doesn't just play music; they create an experience that transports the audience to another era, where the essence of jazz and blues reigns supreme.

Welcome to an evening of superb swing jazz and blues brought to you by the band that is April’s Fools. “We’re absolutely wrapt to be bringing this ultra-talented and experienced combo to the festival,” says Music Director Lee Quayle. “Whenever, and wherever this group of musicians have played reviewers have to search the thesaurus for new superlatives to describe the show, and audiences leave reluctantly, but happy.”

April’s Fools are April Phillips (vocals), Greg Crayford (drums), Zak Dikvert (guitar), Nicholas Bauke-Maunsell (saxophone), Miles Crayford (keyboards) and RoryMacartney (bass). They will be playing at Jazz in Martinborough on Friday 5 September 2025 as the opening of the ticketed festival gigs to be held in the Town Hall.

“It’s a while since we had a big band at the festival, so we’re elated to have the Airforce Jazz Orchestra back with us again.

events.id: Tip Track Marathon: Cloud 9-139B The Parade, Island Bay, Wellington 6023, New Zealand-Facebook
events.name: Tip Track Marathon: Cloud 9
events.venue: 139B The Parade, Island Bay, Wellington 6023, New Zealand
events.long_description:
START TIMES:
7am - Marathon
9am - Half Marathon
Website: tiptrackmarathon.co.nz
Rego: https://tip-track-marathon.lilregie.com/boo.../attendees/new
COURSE DETAILS:
Tip Track Marathon (TTM) –
Tip Track Marathon is an out-and-back, out-and-back, out-and-back, out-and-back, out-and-back, out-and-back type course that has proven popular with participants. Each of the six laps is slightly over 7km, with around 400m in elevation (2500m in total). Try not to trip on a loose rock while taking in the aromatic smells emanating from the tip. Ignore the gale-force northerly. It makes for a challenging marathon but you can find comfort in the other runners suffering too.
Recommended donation: $40
Half Marathon -
For those that hate themselves but not as much as the marathoners. Same course as above but three laps instead of six,
Recommended donation: $25
Tip Track Marathon (TTM) is a low-key, no frills trail running race that takes place at the Tip Track in Wellington each year - all in the name of charity. TTM is all about hard hills, high-fives, and doing something stupid for the sake of it. There are no prizes. Your workmates will not understand why you did this. It’s not even that fun.
This is a race for those that want a little more from life than the ordinary. Those that question the monotony of their daytime jobs and wonder, "isn't there meant to be more to life than this?" Enter TTM... I mean, you won't find any answers here but those are the people that tend to be attracted to it.
DONATIONS:
All entry fees charged go to our charities for 2025:
Youthline Wellington
Social Supermarket
There is a recommended donation amount for each race of $40 (TTM) or $25 (Half). These are recommended only. If you are not in a position to donate, then give whatever you can, if you earn a bit more then feel free to pop in a bit more.
Previous years we have raised:
2024 - $5,500 for the Social Supermarket and OMF
2023 - $5,125 for the Social Supermarket
2022 - $3,600 split between Trailblazers and Wellington Women's Refuge
2021 - $3,770 split between Trailblazers and Wellington Women's Refuge
2020 - $3,376 split between Challenge 2000 and Wellington Women's Refuge

events.description:
If you have not planned for your retirement, then this course is you!
This course has been developed for people in their 50’s or 60’s that are looking at retirement and have no idea if they can financially survive it: what to do, what $’s they need, how or where they can generate additional income, or even where to go to get help.

A step by step planning process will be taught by working through a case study.
Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel.

Please bring pen and paper and wear clothing and footwear suitable for a workshop environment.
By the end of the course, you'll be able to: • Create a silver band • Demonstrate techniques for working sterling silver • Perform metal forming, piercing and texturing skills • Use essential jewellery-making tools accurately Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel.

events.id: Secure Development Training - September 2025-level 7/117 Lambton Quay, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Secure Development Training - September 2025
events.venue: level 7/117 Lambton Quay, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Have you been to a Kawaiicon and found yourself realising that you want to know more? Are you a curious developer who wants to know what happens if you prod a web application? Are you a QA looking to take the worst path possible through an app?
Maybe the PrivSec Secure Development Training is for you!
Agenda
The training is a one day course consisting of the following:
A detailed overview of the OWASP Top Ten Web Application vulnerabilities.
Multiple real world examples and case studies of exploited vulnerabilities.
Hands on experience exploiting these vulnerabilities on a custom web application
Techniques and tooling to identify and exploit these bug classes, using both source code analysis and dynamic testing techniques.
Remediation steps and techniques to mitigate and avoid these issues.
Outcomes
By the end of the day, you will have an understanding of tools and techniques used to compromise web applications and hands on experience in exploiting multiple vulnerabilities in the OWASP top ten.
About the Trainer
Training will be led by one of our Senior consultants, Jack Moran and supported by Sriram Jayaraman
Jack is a Senior Consultant at PrivSec Consulting. He has worked in the offensive security space for the better part of a decade, focusing on web and mobile application testing, along with code reviews and security configuration reviews. He has a number of CVEs credited to himself, and his enthusiasm towards security security is infectious.
Sriram is an ex-developer, turned security consultant. He has a strong background in web application penetration testing, along with code review. He has familiarity with several programming and scripting languages and frameworks such as Python, Javascript, PHP, Node.js, Angular and React.
Notes for the Day
Lunch and snacks will be provided. We will teach you how to hack.

Hands on experience exploiting these vulnerabilities on a custom web application Techniques and tooling to identify and exploit these bug classes, using both source code analysis and dynamic testing techniques.
Outcomes By the end of the day, you will have an understanding of tools and techniques used to compromise web applications and hands on experience in exploiting multiple vulnerabilities in the OWASP top ten.

events.venue: Level, 11/15 Willeston Street, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.description:
ECD Emotional Strategy Development 1 Day Certification Course Become a Certified Emotional Culture Deck Change Practitioner Apply The ECD to manage change effectively by harnessing the collective emotions of your people and teams.
“Change is emotional.
This certificate serves as a testament to your commitment to emotional leadership and amplifying human conversations about what really matters in the workplace 90-Day All Access Pass to our Online Elephant Rider Community: By enrolling, you gain 90 days of access to online ECD resources, expertise, and continued support, all designed to flip the traditional approach to Change Strategy development Your Emotional Change Toolkit: As part of the Course, you gain access to a change toolkit, designed to enrich your learning and application of change mastery.

events.id: The Liberal International Order as a Core-Periphery Order: An Alternative History with Multiple Deep Contestations-room 101/16 Kelburn Parade, Kelburn, Wellington 6012, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: The Liberal International Order as a Core-Periphery Order: An Alternative History with Multiple Deep Contestations
events.venue: room 101/16 Kelburn Parade, Kelburn, Wellington 6012, New Zealand
events.long_description:
I offer an alternative macrohistory of the Liberal International Order (LIO) that was explicitly designed to perpetuate Western dominance and American hegemony. The LIO is better understood as a core-periphery order because inequality between the Western-core and the ‘Restern’-periphery was constitutive of it. (Re-)Imperialism—not just liberalism—remained a central ordering mechanism well after 1945. I show the two-way deep contestations between the liberal and anticolonial ordering projects, especially at the 1955 Bandung Conference. Contra the post-LIO pessimism of disorder/chaos, I argue that the normative agency of the Southeast Asian states informed by the legacy of Bandung is heralding a multiplex, multi-regional world order. As the declining inequality between the West and Asia transforms the core-periphery LIO, the emergent decentered world order will lack a core, whether Western/liberal or Asian. This deep transformation should be welcomed, not deeply contested, although coexistence and global integration require embracing deep pluralism, not liberalism.
Manjeet S. Pardesi is Associate Professor of International Relations in the Political Science and International Relations Programme, and Asia Research Fellow at the Centre for Strategic Studies at Victoria University of Wellington. His research interests include World Orders and World/Global History, Great Power Politics, Asian security, and the Sino-Indian rivalry. His most recent book, Divergent Worlds: What the Ancient Mediterranean and Indian Ocean Can Tell Us About the Future of International Order (co-authored with Amitav Acharya) was published by Yale University Press in 2025.
events.description:

(Re-)Imperialism—not just liberalism—remained a central ordering mechanism well after 1945.

events.id: Biochar Big Day Out 2025-255 Otaki Gorge Road, Ōtaki, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Biochar Big Day Out 2025
events.venue: 255 Otaki Gorge Road, Ōtaki, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Char curious? Keen gardener? Orchardist? Lifestyler? Climate Champion? BBQ enthusiast? 
Come one, come all to this one-off opportunity to spend a day making biochar in a magical orchard, forest and garden. Thank you Kapiti Coast District Council (KCDC) and Paekākāriki Orchards and Gardens (POG) for sponsoring this event so we can offer subsidised tickets as part of Sustainable Spring!
You will:

Morning sessions (9.30-12)...
Sipping coffee and learning the basics of Biochar. 
Getting hands-on exploring the property and learning to source good burn material (stuff you can find in your own backyard or lifestyle block).
Building a char toilet - great skills for civil defence emergencies, or just camping!
Ignite the Char-B-Que and BIG 600l kiln, learn how to feed the flames and trap the carbon.
Cooking using char!
At lunchtime (12-1)...
Enjoy a BBQ lunch cooked on the Char-B-Que. 
Learn all about the magic of biochar and how to use it to fight climate change, feed your garden. 
After lunch sessions (1-3)...
Quenching (pour cold water on) a kiln and processing char by drying and crushing it.
Making a home fireplace mini kiln using a biscuit tin (please bring a tin if you have one or koha for some extra we will source and bring from op shops).
Making a char water filter.
At the end of the day (3 pm)
Grab some biochar to take home (BYO container e.g. ice-cream tub or a small bucket
The big kiln will be quenched later in the day (around 4pm). For those keen to level up their learning on the kind of kilns used for large lifestyle blocks and small farms you are welcome to stay on and participate in a small advanced group dicussion and actvities between 3 and 4.30pm. 
Important things to note: 
Sustainability: 
We encourage carpooling to the event. Please bring your own reusable cup for hot drinks
Health and Safety:
 Please note there will be tree nuts and hazards onsite such as hot kilns and flames. So please take the necessary precautions by wearing non-flammable (cotton, wool, natural) materials and bring any personal medication that you need. We will have a health and safety volunteer onsite.

Family Friendly:
 It is a family-friendly event (kids under 18 are free) but they must be supervised by their parent or guardian at all times due to the hazards on site. 
Workshop Leaders 
John Wraight - CharPae 
Our CharPae Operations manager and ‘inhouse’ Biochar subject matter expert John Wraight has been making and using Biochar for many years and has delivered a number of successful workshops using these kilns. He is a BioChar Network member. He leads local CharPae burns, Char-B-Ques and kiln hire.
Holly Norton - CharPae 
Our CharPae Project manager has been making and using Biochar for the past 2 years. She co-leads these workshops and has additionally been exploring char use in sustainable construction and civil defence. She is currently on a mission to use Biochar to transform a tennis court into a thriving kai production space. She is this event's coordinator should you have any questions.
events.description:
Enjoy a BBQ lunch cooked on the Char-B-Que.

events.id: Folk Bitch Trio-San Fran, Wellington-Ticket Master
events.name: Folk Bitch Trio
events.venue: San Fran, Wellington
events.description:
Folk Bitch Trio Debut headline show in Te Whanganui-a-Tara/Wellington Melbourne’s alluring Folk Bitch Trio have announced their debut album release tour of New Zealand, playing headline shows in Auckland, Wellington & Christchurch.
Now Would Be A Good Time, the debut album by Folk Bitch Trio, tells vivid, visceral stories.
It wasn’t long before she messaged Peverelle and Sinclair, asking if they’d be interested in starting a “folk bitch trio.”  As soon as they started singing together, their connection deepened, and “the chemistry of being inspired by each other was evident from the get-go,” says Sinclair.
Listening to Folk Bitch Trio, it’s clear that this is a band of three distinct points of view, with contrasting and complementary backgrounds and visions.
Sinclair is the self-proclaimed jester of the group, but her taste skews dark, gothic, baroque and dramatic, expressed as a love of opera and ballet as well as musicians as wide-ranging as Patti Smith, Nirvana and Tchaikovsky.

events.id: Draw It Out - Teens workshop 29 Sept-level 2/105 High Street, Hutt Central, Lower Hutt 5010, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Draw It Out - Teens workshop 29 Sept
events.venue: level 2/105 High Street, Hutt Central, Lower Hutt 5010, New Zealand
events.description:
Theme: Strengthening self-resources Learn how to listen to your feelings and find guidance from within, using a gentle powerful tool called Interactive Drawing Therapy.
This single workshop helps teens to use drawing to access their inner resources, because often they have the guidance within, and just need help to bring it out.
Dates This is a single workshop: 4.15pm-5.30pm Monday 29 September – Strengthening self-resources Cost $46 total Included in each session You will be guided by Lara Phillips, a trained creative facilitator in Interactive Drawing Therapy, through drawing prompts (similar to a guided meditation or journaling) to draw out where you are at and draw out your own inner guidance.
With a 20 year career in creative copywriting in design and communication, she shares drawing and writing as a mode for wellness and self-care, to promote preventative and proactive mental health measures through creativity.
Participants understand it is their own responsibility to manage their mental and physical health during sessions, to opt in and out of activities as they see fit, and make the facilitator aware if further support is required.

events.description:
A gentle yet powerful tool for wellness (adults 18+) to access inner guidance.
Date This is a single workshop 6.15pm-7.30pm Monday 29 September Cost $46 total Included in each session You will be guided by Lara Phillips, a trained creative facilitator in Interactive Drawing Therapy, through drawing prompts (similar to a guided meditation or journaling) to draw out where you are at and draw out your own inner guidance.
This gentle yet powerful tool uses drawing and writing as a way to access your subconscious and to listen to your heart rather than your head for guidance.
With a 20 year career in creative copywriting in design and communication, she shares drawing and writing as a mode for wellness and self-care, to promote preventative and proactive mental health measures through creativity.
Participants understand it is their own responsibility to manage their mental and physical health during sessions, to opt in and out of activities as they see fit, and make the facilitator aware if further support is required.

events.description:
Gate opens 7pm Music Starts 7.30pm Wednesday 1st October 2025 Auckland based Albi and the Wolves set fire to stages and fill hearts with hope with their energetic and relatable alternative indie folk songs.
Proud albino frontman Albi (Chris Dent), Pascal Roggen and Michael Young have crafted a stage show brimming with energy yet with pauses for reflection.
The trio has a huge sound created simply by acoustic guitar, electric violin, double bass and three voices.
Since 2014, Albi & the Wolves have gone from strength to strength touring Australia, New Zealand and Rarotonga.
In 2018, they took home the Best Folk Artist Award at the NZVMAs.

events.venue: Secret Location, Wellington
events.description:
Very special guests TBA Bec Sandridge is hitting the road with her band to celebrate her bratty new single Always A Fan.
Expect melodrama, bigger hooks, fuzzed-out guitars, and a few unsolicited overshares—delivered with grit and polish.
Known for her theatrical, no-holds-barred live show, Sandridge has played Falls Festival, World Pride, Groovin the Moo, Indiestad and London Calling, toured the UK and Europe, and supported Mitski, St. Vincent, Saah Blasko, Yungblud, Ladyhawke, Kimbra, and Tegan and Sara.
Her new single Always A Fan—co-produced with Nick Zaharias (MAY-A, The Buoys)— featuring collaborators like Tony Buchen (G Flip, Smashing Pumpkins), Dave Jenkins Jr (Daniel Johns, Vera Blue, and multi-Grammy-winner Cian Riordan (St Vincent, Billie Eilish, Lana Del Rey).
Her 2024 Great Southern Nights show was the first in the series to sell out.

events.id: 5Rhythms workshop with Natalie Poole - Archaeology: Uncovering the Bones-98 The Parade, Paekākāriki 5034, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: 5Rhythms workshop with Natalie Poole - Archaeology: Uncovering the Bones
events.venue: 98 The Parade, Paekākāriki 5034, New Zealand
events.description:
A full 5Rhythms® weekend workshop in Paekākāriki, Wellington, New Zealand Join us for a deep dive into the skeletal landscape of the body—where form and movement provoke the memory of our animal, and mineral cells/selves.
In this weekend immersion, we’ll uncover the bones—exploring the structure, strength, support, and vitality that arise when we embody our bony architecture.
Through the 5Rhythms map, we’ll trace, align, and articulate the inner scaffolding that grounds our shapes, holds us upright, and upon which we can align our sense of self.
Her approach weaves embodied storytelling, deep listening, and transformative movement.
All willing movers are welcome.

events.description:
DOORS 6:00 pm SHOW START 6:30 pm Tim Freedman is the lead singer, songwriter and pianist of legendary Australian folk rock group The Whitlams.
He will perform the best of his renowned nine album repertoire with pedal steel and electric guitarist Ollie Thorpe.
Since 2022 a reinvigorated Freedman has led The Whitlams in a resurgence, touring heavily and releasing two new albums “Sancho” (2022) and the Americana tinged “Kookaburra” (2024).
Between band tours he has started performing smaller country towns in duo mode, and this piano/pedal steel configuration has developed delicate atmospherics to suit the poignant narratives in Freedman’s songs.
In September The Whitlams will performs three shows with the Melbourne Symphony Orchestra.
